name: Retail Store Checkout Redesign - Discovery Phase
description: Discovery phase only for physical retail store checkout experience. Shows divergent exploration in familiar context

inputs.context: Large retail chain with 500+ stores. Customer satisfaction scores dropping, checkout identified as pain point. Goal: understand checkout problems before designing solutions
inputs.initialResearch: In-store observations at 10 locations (50 hours), customer exit interviews (n=200), cashier interviews (n=30), checkout time analysis, competitive observation

userInsights.insight: Customers and staff have conflicting priorities: customers want speed, staff need thoroughness
userInsights.evidence: Customers get frustrated when cashiers ask loyalty program questions. Cashiers stressed by rushing through required steps
userInsights.userQuote: Customer: 'Just let me pay and go!' Cashier: 'I have to ask about the rewards card - it's required'

userInsights.insight: Payment friction point: customers fumble with wallets, cards, phones while holding bags
userInsights.evidence: Average 45 seconds of fumbling with payment. Customers juggling items, putting down bags, searching for wallet
userInsights.userQuote: I'm trying to hold everything, get my card out, and the cashier is already scanning the next person's stuff

userInsights.insight: Loyalty program enrollment creates bottleneck but customers don't understand value
userInsights.evidence: Avg 2.5 minutes to enroll in loyalty program. 60% of enrollees can't recall benefits when asked after
userInsights.userQuote: The cashier signed me up for something but I don't remember what it was or why I need it

userInsights.insight: Bag packing creates delay and awkwardness about customer vs. staff responsibility
userInsights.evidence: Unclear bag packing protocol. Some customers help, some don't. Creates social awkwardness and delay
userInsights.userQuote: I never know if I should bag my own stuff or if they'll get offended. So I just stand there awkwardly

userInsights.insight: Self-checkout creates anxiety about making mistakes and looking incompetent
userInsights.evidence: 42% avoid self-checkout entirely. Those who use it appear anxious, frequently look for help
userInsights.userQuote: I'm worried I'll scan something wrong and look like I'm stealing. Or it'll beep and everyone will stare

userInsights.insight: Price checks mid-transaction create embarrassing delays
userInsights.evidence: When item doesn't have price, staff must leave to check. Customer and line wait awkwardly. Often customer declines item
userInsights.userQuote: When they had to do a price check, I felt so guilty about holding up the line. I just said forget it

marketInsights.insight: Amazon Go's 'Just Walk Out' technology shows checkout elimination is possible
marketInsights.competitorAnalysis: Computer vision tracks items, charges automatically. Eliminates checkout entirely
marketInsights.opportunity: Could RetailMax pilot checkout-free experience in select locations?

marketInsights.insight: Mobile payment adoption varies by demographic and store location
marketInsights.competitorAnalysis: Apple Pay/Google Pay used in 15-40% of transactions depending on location
marketInsights.opportunity: Optimize checkout for mobile payment as primary method in high-adoption stores
marketInsights.trend: Shift from cash/card to mobile payments

problemAreas.description: Customers want fast checkout, company requires loyalty questions and accuracy checks, creating tension
problemAreas.userImpact: Customer frustration, staff stress, perceived slow service

problemAreas.description: Customers juggle items and payment methods, creating friction and delays
problemAreas.userImpact: 45-second payment fumbling, dropped items, line delays

problemAreas.description: Enrollment is slow and value is unclear, creating bottleneck without clear benefit
problemAreas.userImpact: 2.5-minute enrollment, customer confusion, low engagement with program

problemAreas.description: Anxiety about mistakes and theft appearance prevents adoption
problemAreas.userImpact: 42% avoid self-checkout, underutilized capacity, longer staffed lines

userBehaviors.context: Customers organize items by category before scanning

userBehaviors.behavior: Preparing payment while items being scanned
workarounds: Putting bags on floor to free hands

userBehaviors.behavior: Avoiding eye contact during loyalty question
userBehaviors.context: When cashier asks about rewards card
userBehaviors.motivation: Hoping to skip the question by not engaging

stakeholders.perspective: Want fast, frictionless checkout without awkwardness or judgment
Trying to balance speed, accuracy, and required procedures while managing customer frustration
Want to maximize loyalty enrollment while maintaining customer satisfaction and efficiency
Want data-driven insights into customer behavior and loyalty program effectiveness

assumptions.assumption: Customers want to get through checkout as fast as possible
assumptions.validationMethod: Some customers may value interaction and service over pure speed. Survey and observe different customer segments

assumptions.assumption: Self-checkout is inherently faster than staffed checkout
assumptions.validationMethod: Time both methods with equivalent transactions. Consider error rates and assistance needs

assumptions.assumption: Loyalty program enrollment delay is worth the lifetime value
assumptions.validationMethod: Calculate actual LTV of checkout-enrolled vs. other methods. Survey enrolled customers about engagement

assumptions.assumption: Mobile payment adoption will continue to increase
assumptions.validationMethod: Track adoption trends by demographic and location over time

surprisingFindings: Self-checkout anxiety is about looking like a thief, not technology complexity
Customers actively avoid engaging with cashiers about loyalty programs
Bag packing role ambiguity causes more friction than expected
Price checks create embarrassment, not just delay
contradictions: Store wants customer interaction (loyalty enrollment) but customers want speed
Self-checkout meant to improve speed but anxiety slows many customers
Cashiers want to be helpful but feel pressured to rush
researchGaps: Limited data on high-value customer preferences
Need to observe peak (holiday) vs. normal times
Longitudinal study of loyalty program engagement

nextSteps.rationale: Discovery complete with clear problem areas identified. Ready for definition workshop to converge on specific problem statement and design principles

goals: Synthesize discovery insights into problem statement
Define design principles balancing speed and business goals
Align stakeholders on problem to solve
questions: Is speed the right goal, or is 'frictionless' more accurate?
How important is loyalty enrollment vs. checkout satisfaction?
Should we optimize staffed checkout or push self-checkout adoption?
What role should cashiers play in future checkout experience?
